text: Insects and nematodes transmit many kinds of plant viruses.
The CaMV genome moves from the cytoplasm to the cell nucleus through a nuclear pore.
After virions are assembled in the cytoplasm, virus-encoded proteins, called movement proteins, help transfer the virions through plasmodesmata into an adjacent cell.

Viruses such as tobacco mosaic virus appear to require nonspecific entry into broken cells.
In the field, 10% of cruciferous vegetables are typically infected with caulif lower mosaic virus.
For example, the geminiviruses are inoculated into cells by planteating insects such as aphids, beetles, and grasshoppers.
Usually an oncogene encodes an abnormal form of a host protein that controls cell proliferation.
The integrated viral genome expresses proteins that stimulate host cell division and may ultimately lead to growth of tumors.
Some plant viruses enter the seed and infect the next generation.
Some critics of gene technology fear that the prevalence of the CaMV promoter in transgenic crops may lead to the evolution of new dsDNA genome is transmitted through aphid bite.
